msIdentifier.collection: Civil War & Reconstruction Governors of Mississippi, Main Collection

note.p: Not identified. Contact us at cwrgmproject@gmail.com to provide more information.

Adelbert Ames served as a governor and U.S. senator of Mississippi during the Reconstruction era. He was born in East Thomaston (modern-day Rockland), Maine, in 1835. As a boy, Ames spent time working on various merchant vessels, receiving training in seamanship. He entered the United States Military Academy at West Point in 1856, graduating in May 1861, at the start of the Civil War. Commissioned as a second lieutenant, the young Ames was promoted to first lieutenant barely over a week later and served with the 5th U.S. Artillery during the battle of First Bull Run at Manassas, Virginia, on July 21, 1861. Despite being wounded in the leg, Ames stayed by his cannons. His actions at Bull Run led him to receive the brevet (honorary) rank of major and, in 1893 (more than thirty years later), the Medal of Honor.

Ames recovered from his wound and returned to the front lines in 1862, serving with distinction as an artillery officer during the Peninsula Campaign near Richmond. Seeking better promotion potential, Ames sought an infantry command. Through those efforts, in August 1862, he received command of the 20th Maine Infantry Regiment, and led that unit in combat during the Battle of Fredericksburg in December 1862. In May 1863, he volunteered to serve as a staff officer for Major General George G. Meade, which helped him achieve the rank of brigadier general that month. With this promotion, Ames left the 20th Maine to his second-in-command, Lieutenant Colonel Joshua Lawrence Chamberlain, who gained great fame commanding the regiment at Little Round Top during the Battle of Gettysburg in July 1863. Ames own performance at Gettysburg was highly praised, as his division successfully defended the Union position at Cemetery Hill.

After Gettysburg, Ames division was transferred to the Department of the South. Over the next two years, he commanded Union troops during campaigns in Florida, South Carolina, North Carolina, and Virginia. He received a brevet promotion to major general for his actions at Fort Fisher, North Carolina, in March 1865.

After the Civil War, Ames became involved in federal Reconstruction efforts. In 1868, he was appointed the provisional governor of Mississippi. Ames proved sympathetic to the plight of African Americans in the south. He sought to protect Black civil rights and appointed Mississippis first African American public officials. In 1870, after Mississippi was readmitted into the Union, Ames ran for U.S. senator for the state as a Republican and won. He served in that capacity from February 1870 to January 1874, achieving the reputation as a strong public speaker. While serving as a senator in Washington, D.C., Ames met and married Blanche Butler, daughter of Union general Benjamin F. Butler, under whom Ames had served during the war. Ames and his wife had six children over the course of their marriage.

In 1873, Ames ran for governor of Mississippi. His chief rival was James L. Alcorn, a former Confederate general who had been a Whig before the Civil War and joined the Republican Party afterwards. Ames won the election and worked diligently to improve Mississippis financial and social situation. In 1874, Democrats in Mississippi coordinated a campaign of violence against African Americans and white Republicans in the state, to secure political control in Mississippi. Unable to militarily suppress the white supremacist terror campaign, Ames signed a truce with Democratic leaders in Mississippi to reduce the violence and allow a peaceful election. Groups of white supremacists abandoned the truce and resumed their intimidation tactics against Republicans and Black Mississippians during the following elections, leading to a surge of Democratic politicians taking office.

In 1876, the conservative Democrat majority in the Mississippi legislature tried to impeach Ames and many other Republican officials with trumped up charges of corruption. Despite a strong political force against him, Ames critics were unable to provide any evidence of impropriety. Nevertheless, because impeachment was politically driven, Ames could see that his future as governor was over and any effort on his part to legally defend himself would be personally and financially taxing. He and his attorneys reached an agreement with Democratic leaders to resign his office in exchange for dropping the legal charges. On March 29, 1876, after Democrats cancelled their legal proceedings, Ames vacated his position.

Ames left Mississippi and went into business in Minnesota with his father and brother. A short time later, he relocated to New York City and then Massachusetts, overseeing mills and various business interests. When the Spanish-American War erupted in 1898, Ames volunteered for service and was appointed brigadier general of volunteers. Although over sixty years old, Ames joined the field campaign in Cuba and performed well.
Ames resumed his business ventures in the early twentieth century. He lived until 1933, dying at age 97. He is buried in Lowell, Massachusetts.
(Wikipedia)
Adelbert Ames belonged to the following social groups:
James Thornton Fant was an attorney and judge in Mississippi during the nineteenth century.

Born in Alabama on November 8, 1838, Fant graduated from the University of Mississippi in the late 1850s and became a practicing attorney in Holly Springs, Mississippi. When the Civil War broke out in 1861, Fant volunteered for Confederate service and served in the Ninth Mississippi Infantry Regiment. He was promoted to lieutenant in 1862 and was wounded during the Battle of Munfordville, Kentucky, in September 1862.

After the war he was appointed a district attorney and served in that role for several years in the 1870s. Fant also ran a law firm with his brother, Arthur Fant, and established a good reputation for his legal skills. In 1890, he was appointed circuit judge, to fill the vacancy left by the death of William Rogers. He served for two years and then resigned in 1892. He passed away on August 21, 1895. Fant was married to Clara M. Clayton and had at least one child, who died in infancy. Fant is buried in Hill Crest Cemetery in Holly Springs, Mississippi.

(FindaGrave; Dunbar Rowland, The Official and Statistical Register of the State of Mississippi, 1908, 593; Alfred E. Fant, Fant genealogy, Entry 920; The Clarion-Ledger, Jackson, MS, March 20, 1878; The Semi-Weekly Leader, Brookhaven, MS, August 14, 1890; The State Ledger, Jackson, MS, September 20, 1892)
James T. Fant belonged to the following social groups:
Orlando Davis was an attorney, politician, and judge in Mississippi during the nineteenth century.

Born on September 13, 1813, in Virginia, Davis moved to Ripley, Mississippi, as a young man. He studied law and became a successful attorney in Tippah County. By the 1840s he was active in public and political circles, and ran for state legislature as a Whig. He was a leading Union delegate to conventions in Tennessee and Mississippi held during the national political debate over the Compromise of 1850 and the future of slavery in federal territories gained after the Mexican-American War. Davis continued to be a Union and compromise politician through the 1850s, supporting the Constitutional Union candidate John Bell during the 1860 presidential election. However, after the election of Abraham Lincoln, Davis was a delegate to Mississippi secession convention and ultimately supported the states separation from the Union.

Davis remained in his home town of Ripley and practiced law during much of the Civil War. He provided moral and subsistence support for Confederate troops, being credited with delivering supplies to Mississippi troops in the field. After the war, he served as a circuit court judge. Davis died on August 4, 1898, at the age of 84. He was married to Martha McGee and had at least one child. Davis is buried in Hill Crest Cemetery in Holly Springs, Mississippi.

(FindaGrave; The Semi-Weekly Leader, Brookhaven, MS, August 10, 1898; Holly Springs Gazette, April 6, 1844; The Ripley Advertiser, Ripley, MS, March 2, 1844; The Semi-Weekly Mississippi Free Trader, Natchez, MS, June 20, 1843; Flag of the Union, Jackson, MS, September 12, 1851; The Weekly Mississippian, Jackson, MS, August 8, 1860; The Weekly Mississippi Pilot, Jackson, MS, August 20, 1870)
Orlando Davis belonged to the following social groups:
Issac N. Osborn was a newspaper editor and Republican official in Louisiana and Mississippi after the Civil War.

His origins are unclear, but Osborn was originally from Indiana. He emerged in the public eye in Mississippi in the late 1860s as the newspaper editor of the Mail in Madison, Louisiana, and a resident of Vicksburg, Mississippi. He was openly Republican and was elected a Mississippi state representative in 1869. In 1872 he took the position as the Mississippi State Librarian, serving in that capacity until around 1875. Osborn then took the role of private secretary to Governor Adelbert Ames in the mid-1870s. During the latter part of the 1870s, Osborn served as inspector of customs and then ran for Mississippi legislature as a Republican in 1880. By the mid-1880s, his name no longer appeared in Mississippi newspapers regarding political or social activities, and his fate is unclear.

(Official Register of the United States, Containing a List of the Officres and Employees in the Civil, Military, and Naval Service, 1879, Vol. 1,, 158; The Weekly Mississippi Pilot, Jackson, MS, December 4, 1869; New Orleans Republican, New Orleans, LA, March 6, 1870; The Mississippi Press, Pascagoula, MS, April 27, 1877, October 29, 1880, and April 29, 1881)
Isaac N. Osborn belonged to the following social groups:
Located in Montgomery County, Duck Hill was founded in 1834. (Wikipedia)

Currently located in Marshall County, Holly Springs was founded in 1836 in what was then Monroe County. When Marshall County was created on March 1, 1836, Holly Springs became its county seat. (Rowland, Mississippi, 874; Wikipedia; Atlas of Historical County Boundaries)

Located in Montgomery County, Mississippi, Winona was founded as early as 1848 in what was then Carroll County. It was incorporated on May 2, 1861. When Montgomery County was created on May 12, 1871, Winona became the county seat and remains so today. (Wikipedia; Atlas of Historical County Boundaries)

gloss.p: "The agency of a factor who in the customary course of his business has authority binding on his principal to buy or to sell goods, to consign goods for sale, or to raise money by pledging goods." (Merriam-Webster Dictionary)
"'An area of land, together with a house and buildings, used for growing crops and/or keeping animals as a business.' (Cambridge Dictionary)"
Engaging in "illegal activities." (Cambridge Dictionary)
"The crime of illegally entering a building and stealing things." (Cambridge Dictionary)
"The crime of stealing from somewhere or someone." (Cambridge Dictionary)
"The processing of individuals who have committed criminal acts." (Cambridge Dictionary)

catDesc.term: Criminal Procedures--Charges and Specifications (Civil and Criminal)

gloss.p: "To make a formal statement saying that someone is accused of a crime." (Cambridge Dictionary)
"Having officially been found guilty of a crime in a law court." (Cambridge Dictionary)

"If someone who has committed a crime is pardoned, that person is officially forgiven and their punishment is stopped." (Cambridge Dictionary)"An act of mercy by a person in authority toward someone who has committed a crime, esp. by reducing a punishment." (Cambridge Dictionary)
"The hearing of statements and showing of objects, etc. in a law court to judge if a person is guilty of a crime or to decide a case or a legal matter." (Cambridge Dictionary)
"A person who is in charge of a trial in a court and decides how a person who is guilty of a crime should be punished, or who makes decisions on legal matters." (Cambridge Dictionary)
"Someone whose job is to give advice to people about the law and speak for them in court." (Cambridge Dictionary)
"A person with special training in the medical field." (Cambridge Dictionary)
"A medical doctor, especially one who has general skill and is not a surgeon." (Cambridge Dictionary)

Someone who works in an office, writing letters, making phone calls, and arranging meetings for a person or for an organization. (Cambridge Dictionary) CWRGM includes people who perform administrative assistance under this tag, but we do not include government positions that incorporate the word secretary, such as Secretary of State, under this subject tag.

Operating at the state level, the Executive Department of the State of Mississippi consists of the governor, lieutenant governor, secretary of state, state treasurer, state comptroller, commissioner of agriculture, commissioner of insurance, the Mississippi Public Service Commission, the Mississippi Transportation Commission, and attorney general. Each official is elected for a four-year term and is appointed duties pertaining to state regulations. (Wikipedia)

catDesc.term: African Americans--Historically Free and Newly Freed
catDesc.note:
Categories:
Social Identifiers -- Races, Ethnicities, & Nationalities
Social Identifiers -- Labor & Class
Social Identifiers -- Legal Statuses

gloss.p: Historically free African Americans included people who were both African American and lived as and/or were legally free before the American Civil War. They may or may not have previously been enslaved. In recognition of African American military service during the Revolutionary War, a number of states moved to gradually abolish slavery leading to a growing body of free African Americans.

Freedom, however, did not mean citizenship, and despite efforts by free Black activists to settle this question and affirm their citizenship, it was largely left to state lawmakers who otherwise failed to settle the question. Consequently, during the Antebellum era, each southern state passed different laws governing the place and rights of free African Americans. Home to the nation's largest free African American community, for example, Baltimore, Maryland registered 25,000 free Black residents by 1850. (Martha S. Jones, Birthright Citizens: A History of Race and Rights in Antebellum America, p. 13)

In another example, South Carolina's Act of 1820 distinguished between those freed before and after 1820, and classified free African Americans as "denizens," which limited citizenship rights by a series of Black Codes. In response to rebellions, numerous states passed legal restrictions that made manumission virtually impossible by the mid-nineteenth century. Loved ones who purchased family members were forced to legally hold them in bondage, leading to a body of people who "were free by practice, but not by law." (Amrita Chakrabarti Myers, Forging Freedom, 34, 207)

Unlike South Carolina, Mississippi's judiciary ruled that free negroes . . . are to be regarded as alien enemies or strangers prohibited, and without the pale of comity, and incapable of acquiring or maintaining property in this State which will be recognized by our courts. (Heirn v. Bridault, 37 Miss. 209, 22425, 1859 in Jones, Birthright Citizens, p. 213) The state's strict provisions on manumission led to an extremely small population of free African Americans (773 people by 1860) during the antebellum era ("Free Blacks in Antebellum Mississippi," Mississippi Encyclopedia)

Newly freed African Americans includes people who were enslaved but became free by the passage of the Emancipation Proclamation and/or the Thirteenth Amendment. While neither was comprehensive, the Emancipation Proclamation of 1863 freed the enslaved in territories under rebellion, and later the Thirteenth Amendment of 1865 abolished slavery altogether, except when used as a punishment for those who committed a crime and did not apply to Native Nations who practices slavery. (American Battlefield Trust; Wikipedia) In the CWRGM collection, African Americans after December 6, 1865 are classified as historically free or newly freed.

term.rs: African Americans--Historically Free and Newly Freed

catDesc.note:
Categories:
Social Identifiers -- Races, Ethnicities, & Nationalities

gloss.p: The Cambridge Dictionary classifies "a person who lives in the U.S. and is a member of a race of people with dark skin that originally came from Africa" as African American, but both the nineteenth-century and modern constructions are more complex (Cambridge Dictionary). Common nineteenth-century racial categories such as "mulatto" referred to persons with both white and black ancestry, and the experiences of mixed-race persons varied based on complexion, degree of African ancestry, and the region in which they lived. In antebellum cities with large populations of free Blacks, the degree of one's African ancestry could determine what rights one possessed or did not possess, and people with lighter skin tones were often considered to be white; this ended under "one drop rule" during the Jim Crow system.

Like skin tone, the ethnicity implied by the term "African American" is also problematically broad, as "naming people only by the continent of their origin and ignoring their ethnic identity is a consequence of time and space" (Painter, Creating Black Americans, 5). The experience of slavery complicated the term by attempting to strip people of their original distinct African ethnic identities such as Ibo or Ndongan, classifying all persons of African descent together under one term, infusing that term with negative connotation, and disregarding the complex and rich linguistic, cultural, and ethnic histories of varied African people. However, many Black Americans have reclaimed the term "African American" and infused it with positive connotations. One scholar argues that "in using the term 'African Americans,' Black Americans accent the part of their heritage that is not American" (Painter, Creating Black Americans, 4).

CWRGM acknowledging the multiplicity of the term's meanings and connotations includes multiracial and multiethnic people of African descent under the "African Americans" social identifiers subject tag to reflect the diversity of the African American experience and to ensure that the experiences of African Americans of mixed races and ethnicities are discoverable as they are rarely distinguished further in the letters. In the absence of other references, CWRGM also tags racial slurs targeted at African Americans which were common in nineteenth century documents with white authors under the "African Americans" tag. CWRGM recognizes the historic and present harm caused by such language and does not condone its use but tags these terms only to ensure the rich history of African Americans are discoverable within the collection.

term.rs: African Americans--Historically Free and Newly Freed

div.p: [note] 3/10/75 [/note]
[seal]

To His Excellency, Hon. A. A. Ames,
Governor of the State of Mississippi.

We the undersigned citizens of Montgomery County, and vicinity having heard all the circumstances connected with the conviction of Booker Eskridge, and believing him innocent of the charge preferred, and wishing the ends of justice vindicated, would respectfully solicit your Honor to pardon him, the said Booker Eskridge.We believe him innocent for the following reasons.

First. The most reliable one (If an individual concerned in housebreaking could be considered reliable at all) of those engaged in the breaking into the Store of Messrs. Trotter. and Allen. stated on oath, that the said Booker. Eskridge. was not one of the party who broke into said store, and stole goods therefrom.
Second. None of the goods taken from said store were ever found in his possession.
Third. The parties that testified to his guilt, were the most unreliable men and women in the vicinity of Duck Hill, the town in which said store is located.
Fourth. Goods were found in the possession of all the others who were proven to be concerned in said burglary.
Fifth. Two of the witnesses who testified to the said Booker Eskridge's guilt, had been previously convicted of the same offense.

Sixth. The said Booker Eskridge worked on a farm and made a good crop during the year said burglary was committed and all the other partieswitnesses included lived in the town of Duck Hill without any occupation whatever.

Therefore in view of all those circumstances connected with the said Booker Eskridge's case, we the undersigned pray your Honor again to pardon him the said Booker Eskridge, and ^we^ will forever pray, &c

Signed.
Henry Jernigan. His mark X
Green Bankston. " " X
Henry Bankston " " X
Caesar. Russell " " X

Refer to Judge Davis & Dist Atty.
A A
Inform Dr H. H. Hudgins Winona Missof final action
Holly Springs, March 10, 1875.

I cannot give the least Countenance to this petition. The testimony Showed that three or four persons entered into a conspiracy to commit a series of burglaries on a certain store in Duck Hill, and it satisfied my mind that Booker Eskridge, the petitioner, was the ringleader of the whole concern. It was in proof that he made the false key that gave admisoin to the store house.
I regard the whole petition, as the merest special pleading

O. Davis
Judge &c.
I fully concur in the above remarks of Judge Davis, & for the reasons there given withhold my recommendation to the petition.
The Deft was convicted after a fair and impartial trial & from the evidence I thought Booker Eskridge, the leading spirit in the matter

Jas T. Fant
District Attorney
Eskridge. B.

EXECUTIVE OFFICE,
STATE OF MISSISSIPPI.
Montgomery County.

From H. H. Hudgins
Address Winona
Dated [gap] /75
Received Mar. "
Answered [gap]
Petition for the pardon of Booker Eskridge.
No action.
